text: It didn’t start with an ambulance. It started with pain. Not just any pain — character development pain. The kind that wakes you up at 3am, folds you in half like a crusty yoga mat, and whispers, “Good luck, bitch.”

You were a 'good patient,' remember? You played the game. You did the fiber. The yoga. The low FODMAP sad beige diet. You smiled through the lectures, the pamphlets, the 'have you tried breathing?' energy. You even kept your voice calm while the 12-year-
       resident explained your own body to you like he was giving a TED Talk called 'It’s Just IBS, Sweetheart.'

You’re not a doctor, but you are a PhD in physics with decades of lived experience in 'something is very wrong with my stomach and no one believes me.' You’ve worked in high-tech labs, helped launch 3D-printed medical devices, and now? You’re curled in the fetal position, vibrating like a dying Roomba, covered in flop sweat and regret.
You haven’t eaten in three days. A bite of yogurt sent you into a full-body exorcism. Even water is playing hard to get.

Your boss at the 3D printing job — the same one who praised you when you worked through fevers and nausea — called you lazy and put you on a PIP for daring to deteriorate. Because chronic illness makes you unproductive, and unproductive is unacceptable.
Your partner tiptoes in, haunted. 'Do you think it’s time to go to the ER?'
You nod. The Go Bag is already packed.

choices.text:
🚑 Tell him to call 911, because your legs don’t work and your soul has already left the building.
You’ll have to deal with whatever sentient jar of mayonnaise shows up in uniform — but at this point, who cares?

🚗 Let him drive you — which is only slightly less dangerous than letting a squirrel operate a forklift.
He’s also chronically ill. He can’t sit upright for more than ten minutes without needing two weeks of recovery and a priest. But he’d do it. For you.

🛁 Refuse both. Try to tough it out. Die on the bathroom floor like a true wellness girlie.
Maybe drag out that crusty yoga mat from under the bed. Pretend it’s helping. Try not to aspirate your own stomach acid. Spoiler: you’ll end up needing 911 anyway.

resources.title: Patient Advocacy Scripts
items: Keep a symptom journal and bring it to appointments.
Prepare a 30-second summary of your symptoms and history.
Ask: 'What else could this be?' and 'Can we rule out a motility disorder?'
Request documentation if denied tests or referrals.

text: You call 911. The paramedics show up with a clipboard, zero compassion, and strong 'I peaked in high school' energy. One of them immediately asks if you're pregnant with twins.
You'd laugh if your stomach weren't actively trying to kill you.

choices.text: 🤷 Let them do their thing (bad idea)
📢 Try to explain your condition calmly

text: Your partner grabs the keys with a grimace. He can barely sit up, but he’s doing his best.
Every pothole is a medieval torture device. Every stoplight is a spiritual trial.

choices.text: 🚑 Change your mind and call 911 instead
🛬 Arrive at the ER barely holding it together

text: You drag out the crusty yoga mat. You lay there in a pool of sweat and Ensure and bargaining.
Spoiler: you're still going to the ER. You’re just going to suffer longer first.

choices.text: 📱 Film a TikTok about your demise
